This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Sunday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: FRANCE AND NORTHERN AFRICA.
div.p: The spectacle offered by the economic and social crisis in South Africa, where Chinese labour alone would seem to be capable of the "Times" Paris correspondent writes, inspired that eminent author M. Paul Adam with a brilliantly suggestive forecast of the future. Laying down the postulate that the yellow man is the only one who is tropical climates can satisfactorily de the necessary work, he asks whether it behaves Western civilized Europe to surrender to him for explotation the Niger, Congo, and Zambesi valleys, and his answer is, Yes. Thereupon, following in the wake of M. Onèsime Reclus, whom he does not mentinon, he reminds his compatriots that their navy is inadequate to protect the sea routes between the mother country and French possessions in the Pacific and the Indian Ocean.

Indo-China will eventually, thinks this observer, be wrested from France. New Caledonia and the New Hebrides will follow suit. Soon the French will be able to ensure merely the passage between Marseilles and Tunis-Algeria- Tangier, with the result that "the only exotic Empire of which France can possibly assume the protection is that of Africa. Situated at our very doors, it will become the outlet of our industrial overproduction that is to say, the main source of French wages – when the free Chinaman or any other workman shall have fertilized the soil, excavated the mines, planted the cotton, and regulated the caoutchouc crop. Africa is our sons' kneading through, and the only one that we can protect against the appetites of the rival nations. Thus those politicians who declare that Morocco is not worth a war reveal their ignorance. Our economic future depends upon our supremacy over this Empire. If we let the Germans settle there, close against us the land route to Timbuktu, harbor their cruisers in the bays of this Mussulman coast we lose in advance the enterance of the Dark Continent. We surrender the keys of Algeria and Tunis to our inventerate enimies, who, when all is said, frankly hate us, as they have just proved by arousing this unjust quarrel after our 30 years of loyal resignation.

"Far from yeilding on this point of the globe, it would be better worth while to offer to the diplomatists of Algeciras to exchange all the rest of our colonies scattered over the world against those of West Africa where France would then see her sovereignty guarenteed by the Powers from Tangier to the northern frontiers of the Cape settlements, from Dakar to the western boundaries of the Nile Valley and the region of the great lakes, Thus the Latins, who dislike establishments too far away, would possess at 48 hours distance from Marseilles and Genoa and at two hours from Cadiz the Empire indispensable for their home industry and the life of their working classes."

M. Paul Adam would like to see this policy of reciprocal exchanged for the creation of Imperial and Latin Africa – implying the close alliance of the Italians, Spaniards, and French – immediately put into effect.

div.head: Port Said's Trade.
div.p: The trade of Port Said deoreased last year, the imports falling in vaine from L.E. 287,880 in 1904 to LB. 239,134 and the exports from L.E 873,004 to LE. 82,183.

div.head: The Sudan Post.
div.p: At Khartoum complaints are reiterated of the loss of bank notes enclosed in letters sent by post to Egypt and elsewhere. Probably these complaints are exaggerated.

div.head: Alexandria Foundlings.
div.p: The annual ball given by the ladies of the committee of the Alexandria Foundlings Benevolent Society will take place at the New Khédivial Hotel on the 3rd proxo.

div.head: Egyptian Religion.
div.p: Messrs. Constable and Co. are publishing during the forthcoming spring publishing season a work by Professor Flinders Petrie entitled "The Religion of Ancient Egypt."

div.head: The Hohenzollern.
div.p: We understand that the delayed cargo of the North Geftnan Lloyd S.S. Hohenzollern will arrive at Alexandria, by the Italian S.S. Armonia which is expected from Genoa about the end of next week.

div.head: The Egyptian Cotton Worm.
div.p: A remarkable announcement was made at the last meeting of the British Entomologioal Society, held in London on the 7th inst., when Commander J. J. Walker said be had taken the larva, known as the Egyptian cotton worm, in the Central Paoific Islands, feeding on the tobacco plant. The Finance Ministry has opened a credit of L.E. 6,000 in order to fight the cotton worm here.

div.head: Eastern Telegraph Co.
div.p: This company announces the payment on the 14th of April of a dividend at the rate of 31/2 per cent per annum, less income tax, on the Preference Stock of the com pany for the quarter ending the 31st of March, and an interim dividend of 14 per cent on the Ordinary Stock, free of income tax (the same as a year ago', in respect of profits for the quarter ended the 31st of December, 1905.

div.head: The Temple of Onias,
div.p: Next July, in the Exhibition of Antiquities at University College, there will be on view remarkable results of the researches made by Professor Flinders Petrie, whose latest exploit in long annual antiquarian quests has resulted in the discovery of the site of the Temple of Ouias. The Professor intends to send to the Chief Rabbi (Dr. Hermann Adler), for presentation to one of the London synagogues, the marble shaft of a pillar found on the site of the historic temple.

div.head: Motors in Egypt
div.p: A welcome innovation has been introduced in the annual report of the Customs Administration for the past year. Formerly motorcars were inolnded in the category of imports classified as "Machines à vapenr fixes et demi fixes," but in the report just issued they have a category all to themselves. The total value of these imports last year amounted to L.E. 27,886. Of this amount France's imports were L.E. 19,269 and England's L.E. 5,168. The other countries were very poorly represented, the third àn the list being Belgium with L.E. 911, followed by America with L.E. 877.

div.head: Victoria House.
div.p: The ladies of the entire committee of Victoria House and Nurses Home (the Hon. Mrs. Hopkinaon, Mesdames F. Allen, A. R. Brown, S. H. Carver, and Ward, and Miss Waeber) were 'at home' yesterday afternoon. There was a large number of guests, who were most hospitably entertained by the ladies of the committee. The band of the 1st R. Doblin Foailiers, by kind permission of Col. Bird and the (Beers, was present and discoursed a choice selection of music in the garden ; while inside a performance was given of Liza Lehmann's "The Daisy Chain." The rendering of this charming song cycle by Mrs. W. E Williams, Miss Carver, Rev. R. Ryud, and Mr, Purvis, was greatly appreciated by all present, and a very pleasant afternoon was spent by the guests. Two guessing competitions, or ganised by Mr. L Bandars, which consisted in guessing, respectively, the number of beans in a glass tore bowl and the length of a ribbon placed in a hrap on a table, were won, the first by Mrs. A. R. Brown and the second by Sister Bertha. The prize in the first case was the aforesaid rose bowl and in the second a book on Sir Joshua Reynolds' works.

div.head: Spend your Holidays at Mena,
div.p: The management of Mena House Hotel has arranged special terms for residents of Cairo, Alexandria, and country from the 10th of April to the 10th of May.

div.head: BIRTH
div.p: Preston- At Moharrem Bey, Alexandria, on the 29th March, the wife of A.S. Preston, of a daughter (prematurely).

div.head: Natal Ministery's Resignation. GRAVE CONSTITUTINAL CRISIS.
div.p: The "Times" says that the resignation of the Natal Ministry, in conseqnence of the interference of the Imperial Government in the domestic affairs of the country, has created a grave constitutional crisis. It adds a hope that it may prove a warning to the Government in its future dealings with the Transvaal and the Empire generally. The Government's notion has created a strong feeling throughout the colonies.

div.head: AGITATION IN ABYSSINIA.
div.p: The "Daily Telegraph's" Rome Correspondent says that reports from Abyssinia show that the agitation following on the death of Ras Makonnen is increasing daily, the population desiring a successor to be chosen from Harrar, of which Ras Makonnen was the chief. The Emperor Menelik is credited with the wish to appoint a personage belonging to his staff. Several European countries are endeavouring to seoure privileges in ' Abyssinia, giving credibility to the report that certain Powers of Northern Europe are endeavouring to convoke an international conference to settle the Abyssinian question before Menelik's death.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Yesterday morning H. H. the Khedive gave audience to Sheikh Mohamed Shakir, Mahmoud Pacha Sidky, Baron de Villebois, and Count Kodziebrodzky.
His Highness attended midday prayers today at Koubbeh Mosque.

div.head: GOVERNMENT EMPLOYES.
div.p: We mentioned in a recent issue that the Coonoil of Ministers, at its last meeting, had decided to forbid Government employés to undertake salaried work elsewhere without a written authorisation from the Department to which the functionary belongs, and that any infractions of this regulation would be treated as breaches of official discipline. We understand that these regulations have always been in force and that the decision of the Council of Ministers to again pall attention to them has been in consequence of representations made lately to the Government by brokers and others who complained of certain employés of two different Ministries exercising the calling of land brokers to their prejudice.

We ourselves some months back also called the attention of the authorities to this anomaly and pointed ont that it was manifestly inconsistent and unfair that salaried servants of the State should be allowed to compete in oommercial matters with the general public and hoped that measures would bave been taken to put a stop to such irregularities. The Government apparently took no steps in the matter at the time judging by the fact that now the Council of Ministers has thought fit to come to the decision of formally prohibiting officials from undertaking other than the work the State pays them for.

We quite agree with a Cairo confrèrethat one of the most effectual means of putting a check to the complaints referred to would be to impose upon all Government employés longer working hours, and make them attend office in the afternoon instead of only in the morning as at present, and more so since it bas been decided to raise their salaries to an appreciable extent.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT.
div.p: ARRIVIAL IN CAIRO.
RECEPTION SPOILED BY WEATHER.

Heavy rain in the morning had cooled the air in Cairo yesterday alter Wednesday's oppressive khamaeen, and had also filled the streets with quantities of the particularly tenacious Cairo mad diversified with pools. The weather was clammy, the public, European and native, looked unspeakably miserable in the morning hot cheered up when the olonds lifted a little after midday and promised a slight improvement—a promise which, by the way, was hardly kept. However, the Public Works Ministry rose to the occasion in spite of the depressing infinences of the day, and from noon onwards the streets, along the rente which the Prince and Princess of Wales were to follow, were assiduously swept, cleaned, scraped, and sanded. Qaite early in the afternoon the police began to circulate and the crowd to colleot. The troops followed and began to line the rente, and flags of every nationality (and some imaginary ones) were hang from hotel and house fronts, balconies, and roofs all along the route from the station to Abdeen.

By 4.45 p.m. the troops were in their places and shortly before 5 p.m. the stream of carriages bearing those who were to meet the Prince and Princess at the station ceassd to flow. The railway station square, Pont Limoun, Sharia 'Nobar Pacha, Sharia Kamel, Opera- square, rue Abdio, and Abdio-square were lined with British and Egyptian troops and police. All traffic was suspended, balconies and terraces filled up rapidly, and all wts in readiuess. The police arrangements were perfect, the public seconded them admirably, and it was a very quiet and well-behaved—if rather apathetic—crowd that thronged the pavements and side streets.

At 12.30 p.m. the Royal train left Suez preceded by a pilot engine. Major1 L'Estrange Johnston was in charge, "supported by Capt. Blakeney,Messrs. Trovithiok, Brin, Versohoyle Duke, Ponter and Tita The baggage was in charge of Mr. Peter Balsam, platform inspector, and four men. Major Watson, D.S.O., representing the Khedive, and Mr. M. de C. Findlay, C.V.G, representing Lord Cromer, accompanied the Royal party from nez. The journey was without incident, but a "inoident" inevitably epella "accident" on these occasions there was nothing to deplore in this and it was only to be regretted that the Royal party saw Egypt under the most unfavourable conditions,— threatening rain and lowering sky.

Cairo station was full by 5 p.m. The Khedive and Prince Mohamed Aly were there and with them Ferik Ahmed Zeki Pacha, Grand Master of Ceremonies ; Ferik Youssel Zia Paoba, Chief A.D.C. to H.H. the Khedive ; Lewa Hussein Moharrrm Paoba, 1st A.D.C, to H.H. the Khedive ; the Ministers, the Earl of Cromer, the Advisers, the Under Secretaries of State, the Governor of Cairo, Mr. A. D. Alban, British Consol ; Lews Ellis Mansfield Pacha, Commandant Cairo Cify Police ; Brig. General Bollock and commanding officers and heads of departments of ths Army ol Occupation ; Ferik Sir Reginald Wingate Pacha, Sirdar, and commanding officers and heads of departments of the Egyptian Army, etc.

At 5.25 a m. the train steamed in and the guns of the 5th Battery E.A. fired their sainte, while the guard of honour famished by the 1st Batt K.R.R C. nnder Major Ribertson- Eustace paid the unusual honours. The Prince and Princess were warmly welcomed by the Khedive and Prince Mohamed Aly and by Lord and Lady Cromer as the train stopped. A few minâtes for conservation, presentations and welcomes and the Royal party and their snite were ready to enter the State carriages.
AS SEEN FROM SHEPHEARD'S.

Rain came down at 5.10 p m. and again at 5.20. and greatcoats and umbrellas were in great evidence on Shepheard's terrace. The public here, as elsewhere, bad forgotten or, had not read the programme and the voice of the pessimist exclaiming, "They were timed to arrive at five o'olock and something dreadful must have happened" was heard in the land, ill the thudding of the guns brought all who estrin the front row on the terrace to their feet—to the horror and despair of those who sat or stood behind them and were not of Brobdignagian proportions—and filled all the baloonies and windows in the Sharia Kamel. Illuminations—looking curiously pallid in the doll half-light—made their appearance and flags that presented a woe-begone and draggled appearance were shaken out, and presently the order to slope arms and a general stiffening on the part of soldiers and police, followed By the appearance of a Mounted Police detachment and Mr. Moberly—harbingers of the procession—told us that the Khedive and his Royal guests were coming. Then came ths procession headed by smart-looking troopers of the Body Guard. The precession was formed as follows :—
Detachment Mounted Police.
1 Sergeant 2 men H.H. Body Guard
1 Officer 30 ,, „ „ ,,
First carriage (State Landau, 4 horses).
H.R.H. the Prince or Wales.
H.H. The Khehdive.
1 Officer 30 men H.H.'s Body Guard.
1 Officer 25 men No. 3 Squadron.
Second Carriage (State Landau, 4 horses).
H.R.H. the Princess of Wales.
H.H. Prince Moh. Ali Pacha.
1 Officer 25 men
1 Offioer 26 men No. 3 Squadron.
1 Sergeant 2 men
3rd Carriage.
The Countess of Cromer.
The Earl of Cromer.
Mr. M. de C. Findlay.
4th Carriage.
The Countess of Shaftesbury.
Lt. Col. Sir Arthur Bigge.
Commander Sir Charles Cust, Bart., R.N.
5th Carriage.
The Lady Eva Dugdale.
The Hon. Derek Keppel.
The Earl of Shaftesbury.
Ferik Youssef Zia Paoha.
6th Carriage.
Frank Dugdale, Esq.
Mr. H. S. Montgomery.
Lewa J. K. Watson Pacha.
Commander Bryan G. Godfrey Fausset, R.N.
Detachment Mounted Police.

Candour, alas ! compels me to declare that the public was rather apathetic. True, the Oriental does not cheer, but the European does as a role, especially the Englishman, and there was a certain thinness about the popular welcome—though I must admit that the Princess was loudly cheered, if not so loudly is some of us would have wished. But the day was responsible,—it was cold and murky, all were wet, some were cold, and a warm, bright day would hare been marked by greater euthusiasm.
(From our Last Correspondent.)

Never did Cairo weather play such a shabby trick as it did yesterday. Never in the depths of winter have we had such a day of rain, nor have the streets been in worse condition. Certainly the drop in the temperature was a relief after the sultriness of the past few days, but leaden skies at this time of ths year are almost unknown in this land of sunshine, and but for the variegated orowds that filled the streets one might easily have imagined oneself back in London. No better coin of vantage for watching the afternoon's proceedings could have been chosen than the Continental Hotel, and at a very early hear people congregated on the wide verandah or took their seats on the numerous balconies on high which were gay with multi-coloured flags. There was much to pass the tedium of the hours of waiting, far troupes of soldiers, both British and Egyptian, were constantly passing and repassing, and the native popolace were early also in taking their places on the pavements and aboat the railings of the Eibekieh Gardens. Their various-hued garments, turbans, and tarbooshes (the latter, by the way, mostly covered from the rain with handkerchiefs) all helped to supply weloome notes of colour, and the scarlet coats and white helmets of the Inniskillinge who lined the road, were very welcome for the some reason.

As time went on numerous sand-lodeu carts appeared upon the scene, their contents being rapidly emptied on the sea of mad which had flown in all directions beforetimes. However, well before five o'clock all was nice and tidy, the tain which had endeavoured to damp people's feelings and their clothes thought better of its ill-timed efforts, and everyone woe at attention when H.H. the Khedive passed by in ample time to greet his Royal visiters on their arrival at the station. After a short time of waiting the boom of the sainte announced the foot that the journey to Cairo had been safely accomplished, and again, other another short rims of waiting, the sounds of a band ploying "Marching from Georgia" and "Tie Swanee River" were heard approaching. A detachment of Mounted Police dashed by followed by the Body Guard with their flattering laaoe penous, and then is an open carriage drawn by four horses with coachman and footman brave in scarlet and gold, appeared H.H. the Khedive with his most illustrious guest, the Prince of Wales, in the seat of honour.

There is no accounting far the ways of a cosmopolitan crowd like this in Cairo, but the almost complete silence which reigned throughout the precession struck one as singularly depressing after the usual feu de joieof hnuths which characterize an English crowd under similar conditions. Another Body Guard, and then a murmur of approbation did ron down the lines, is our own gracious and beautiful Qaéeu eleot swept by ia ths oompany of Prince Mohamed Aly Pacha. There was no time to notice her toilette, though one gathered an impression of much luce about her corsage, and a most becoming round toque of tulle or chiffon. But sentiments of admiration were heard on every side, and indeed she looked every inch a Queen.

Lady Cromer, attired in cream with a large black hat, with Lord Cromer and Mr. de C. Findlay, fallowed next in the cortège, and after them came as arranged the varions other ladies and gentlemen of the party. The procession over, the soldiers qaickly left their appointed positions and disappeared, and in a few brief moments the streets were seething again with humanity and, to all bat students of the same, the show was over.

One hears curious side-lights at times like this, and it is said that the native population is immensely impressed by the foot that the Princees will not go to Sakkara on Monday like ordinary mortals upon the back of either camel or donkey, or even in a eandoart, but in a landau, and by a road that is to be especially constructed for the occasion. Who knows bat that by this fact aloue this visit of our future Queen will be remembered for many a generation to come !
TODAY'S DOINGS.

The Prince and Princess of Wales left Abdeen Palace at 11.40 a m. to-day and drove out to Abbassieh, where H.R.H. inspected the 1st Battalion K.R.R.C. on the ground between the British barracks and the officers' quarters at 12.15 p.m.
T.R.H. subsequently launched with Lt. Col. Markham and the officers of the mess. They drove back afterwards, arriving at Abdeen Palace about 3 p.m.

div.head: ROYALTY AT SUEZ.
div.p: Suez, Thursday.
All last night a southerly gale was raging at Suez, accompanied by rain, but towards noon to-day the wind abated.

At about 8 o'clock this morning the Doke and Duchess of Connaught proceeded on board H.M.S. Renown, where they had breakfast, and subsequently, at 10 a.m., they retained on board the Prinz Regent, which vessel entered at noon.

In spite of the rain, there was a large assembly at the Docks station where their Royal Highnesses landed at 12.15, and were received by H.E. the Governor of Suez, Mr. D. A. Cameron, Consol-General, Col. Wateon, A.D.C. to the Khedive, and other officials. The Prince and Princess of Wales and suite left by the Khedive's private train at 19.25. Both the Suez and Dooks stations were beautifully decorated with flags and fresh flowers.
H.M.S. Renown and Terrible entered the Canal at 8 p.m. for Port Said.

div.head: ARRIVAL AT ZAGAZIG.
div.p: Zagazig, Thursday.

The special train conveying T. B. H. the Prince and Princees of Wales and snite arrived at Zagazig station punctually at 3.55 and at 4 p.m. after taking sufficient water, lett for Cairo, stopping en route at Benha. H.B. the Moadir, Mooheb Bey, Col. Tewfik Bey, Commandent of Chsrkieh Police, and Mr. George Discono, British consular agent, were on the platform to greet T.R H. and presented the Princees with a bouquet. The pablic was not allowed on the station platform, which-had been adorned with plants and flags, and the unusual crowding was therefore avoided. T.R.H. looked in exosilent health.

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE
div.p: The annual Customs returns for the trade of the past year have just made their appearance. The statistics for 1905 are prefaced by some very useful tabular statements of Egypt'- tradefor the past 22 years from 1884 to 1905 inclusive. The most valuable portion of these figures are those showing the proportion of English trade with Egypt as compared with other countries, and the plain unvarnished tale thus presented is that our share of the imports and exports are steadily decreasing, for example, the maximum share of imports from England was attained in 1887, when oat ot 1.000 for the total England contributed 398. Last year England's share fell to 321, which is the lowest proportion we have ever attained despite the foot that car political influence was never so high. Germany, meanwhile, has more than octupuled her share of ths imports, In 1887 her proportion to the total was 3: 1000. In 1897 she had increaaed her share nine rimes over, while in 1904 proportion was 50 and last year 44.

The same tale is told in the figures far the export trade. Eagland is constantly absorbing less and less and Germany more and more of Egypt's exports. For example, ia 1884 car share was 677:1000, while Germany did net figure at all, not even shaving a one-thousandth tips,exports. But while we had and fallen year by year to 585 1899, Germany had increased to 27. But last year our share had fallen to 522 while Germany's, was 85. There is no juggling with figures here. The tabular statements are as simple as they can be, each country's, share representing what it bears proportional to the total of a thousand, and the fact therefore remains that while our political influencs increases our proportion of the trade decreases.

div.head: EGYPTIAN POSTAL GUIDE.
div.p: The Egyptian Post-Office Guide for this year has just been issued and contains many new features and improvements on last years' edition. On looking through the beginning, one finds a page, itself an innovation, giving the principal alterations and changed which have taken place in the service during the last year, followed by another on which the contents have been grouped so that what is required can be found at once. Another most useful addition is the table of the principal mails to and from Egypt, again followed by another giving the approximate time taken for a letter- sent to any of the principal towns of the world. The foreign Parcel Post tariff has been thoroughly revised and all the necessary information regarding postage, prohibited articles, etc., has all been brought on the same , table, instead of the tariff being in one and prohibited articles, etc., in another part, as formerly. Appendix XII., which gives the list of poet-offices, has been modified and made clearer, and a great number of new offices and rural lines established this year have been added. There is no doubt that it it a most useful book of refereace and the public will greatly appreciate the above innovations, which are most handy. It can now be obtained at any of the principal post-offices throughout the country on payment of the small sum of P.T. 1.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Conard S.S. Tyria arrived at Liverpool on Wednesday night. The Moss liner Menes arrived yesterday evening from Liverpool via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head: THE FRONTIER DISPUTE.
div.p: AKABA GARRISON REDUCED.
HOPES OF EARLY SOLUTION.
We understand that the Turkish garrison at Akaba has recently been reduced. This gives cause for hope that a satisfactory solution of the frontier difficulty will be qaickly arrived at
The 'Daily Telegraph,"discussing the Akaba dispute, remarks :—

There it no reason for immediate alarm. On the other bend, there is a possibility of complications of a character which is better understood abroad than in England: Of course, hostility to England on the part of Turkey is an isolated Power will not disturb anybody's rest. But Turksy as a cats- paw may scratch unpleasantly. It is largely question of railways and of the control of the high road to India. The plan of a railway from Beyront through Damascus end the Hedjaz to Mecca recommends itself to the Sultan as a means of enabling him to strengthen his rather precarious position in Arabia, and of securing some kind of control over the Red Sea. His zeal in this direction has been quickened by the opening of Port Sudan and the railway connection with Khartoum by way of Berber. By connecting Akaba with Mian, on the Dsmasoas-Mecca line, the Sultan coaid concentrate troops on tbe:BedSeaoout Ths British Government has naturally to watch these schemes with some keenness, not only in so far as their development inight constitute a menace to Egypt, but; as affecting the security of the Red Sea route to Ldio. For, at the same time, the extension of the Bagdad Railway might, in certain contingencies, menace our supremacy in the Persian Gulf. We are not much alarmed by these possibilities, and least of alt by the rumoured project to connect the Méditerranéen end the Red Sea by a new canal from Akaba. But though there is no real ground for anxiety with regard to an incident which is at present of microscopic proportions, and may not develop into a crisis, there is need for watchfulness. The Saltan is a very wily diplomatist, and nothing suits his game—which, to do him jastice, he plays with rare skills better than to set the Powers at loggerheads. Fortunately, the control of car foreign affairs is fat safe hands, and Sir Edward Grey may be trusted to see that' British interests on the various high roads to India are not jeopardised. It is; however, well that the public should be reminded here Akaba, in the Red Sea, and Koweit in the Persian Gulf, are strategic points as important as many other places far more familiar to their ears.

div.head: GERMANY AND TRIPOLI.
div.p: AGITATION ORGANISED FROM CAIRO.
AGITATION ORGANISED FROM CAIRO.

The attitude takern up recently by the Italian Press with regard to Germany's Ceaseless activity in the neighbourhood of the Mediterranean seems to be justified. The "Vita" publishes a telegram recieved from Vienna to the effect that Germany, aided by the Saltan, is preparing to take possession of Tripoli. A German agent has been stationed at Cairo, and is said to have organised at great expense an agitation on behalf of Germany in Tripoli ; one of his methods has bun that of distributing oil onion declaring that the German Emperor is the Sultan of Turkey's best friend.

A German firm , is about to inatal radio telegraphy between Constantinople,.the island of Rhodea, and Tripoli, while a German Mission, said to be scientific, will reach Tripoli soon. In these foots the "Vita" sees soins explanation of the campaign which is being Waged against Italy by the Praes of Germany and Austria, and it laments Italy's inaptitude to profit from its position on the Mediterranean, foe it is evident that Germany hu designs on Tripoli.
The Malta correspondent of the ''Cornera della Sera" says that a German scientific commercial mission, due there in a few days, will proceed to Tripoli end then is, via Fezzan, to the Cameroons.

"Le Tempt" declares that the German propaganda in Tripoli is manipulated "par un certain Oppenheim habitant ta Caire." lt is presumed th it the Parisian newspaper muns Boron Max von Oppenheim attaohé and "conseiller de Légation" at the German Diplomatic Agency and Consulate General at Cairo.

div.head:
THE NATAL TROUBLES.
Postponed Executions.
Resignations of the Minisry.

div.p: The Ministry has confirmed the death sentences on the natives who murdered the policemen. The executions were fixed for Friday, but Mr. Winston Charchill telegraphed to suspend them pending consideration by the Imperial Government. The Hon. C. J. Smythe Prime Minister, refused, but the Governor, under a letter-patent, postponed the execution. The Ministry has resigned.
The most intense indignation prevails here owing to the interfarensa of the Imperial Government at such a critical juncture. (R.)

div.head:
ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
SIGNING OF THE PROTOCOL.

div.p: The delegates expect that the protocol will be signed on the 8th April. (Reuter)
There are various indications that the reactionary regime is resuming sway in Russia.
The Governor General of Finland, a man of Liberal ideas, has resigned, objecting to the reactionary constitution of the commission appointed to consider the franchise and similar questions.
Russian troops are being sent to Finland. (Reuter)

In answer to a question regarding an understanding with Russia for securing the integrity and development of the resources of Persia, Sir E. Grey announced that he could not say more than that the Government in all cases would keep an open door to an amicable understanding. (Reuter)
Cav. Pestalozza, Italian Consul here, has started for Somaliland. He will pay a visit to the Mullah and to the Sultans of Obbia and Mijertains. (Reuter)
The "Slovo" contradiots the news of the approaching retirement of Count Witte. (H.)
The judge has commenced the examination of the case against the board of directors of the Suoreriea Company of Egypt. (Havas)

The New York State Senate has unanimously passed a Bill terminating on the 16th November the tenure of office of all the present directors and trustees of the New York Life and Mutual Life Insurance Companies. (Reuter)
Owing to an explosion in a colliery at Takashima 256 miners have been killed.
The Pas-de-Calais miners have decided by ballot to continue the strike. (Reuter)
The court-martials have acquitted all officers who refused to participate in the enforcement of inventorying. (Reuter)

div.head: THE VITALITY OF ISLAM.
div.p: The Sudan United Mission asks "all Christians in Great Britain and Ireland" to aid in checking the spread of Mohamedanism in the Protectorate of Northern Nigeria. The negroes there number at least ten millions. Until late years the territory was closed, and now, when it has become safe, under British rule, Moslem traders and missionaries, full if energy and real for the frith, are pressing in so fast that it seems likely they may convert the whole population in no long time. Its devotees number a fifth part of the human race, and they multiply fast. The proportion of Moslems in China was imperceptible fifty years ago ; now they are seen in all parts.

A little incident during the war is not forgotten by those who concern themselves with this matter. As the fleet of Admiral Rodjesvensky steamed through the Straits of Malacca to its doom, the native passengers aboard a British ship crowded to the side and spat at it. They would be Chinamen, Malays, Javanese, Bugie, and so forth, Mohamedans, indeed, but men who would not have dreamed of making each a demonstration a few years ago. The Moslems not only increase in number but in seal. The charge is specially striking in Malay lands. Sir Spencer St John noted the beginning of it in Sarawak. He thought it was the activity of Christian missionaries which roused Moslem fervour. "Before the arrival of the clergy," he wrote in the fifties, "the mosque was almost deserted ; now it is crowded. The same effect followed the arrival of the Catholic priests at Brumei." Good men are not to be discouraged on that account, nor even by their failure to convert any followers of Islam. Sir Frank Swettenham asserts that "Missionaries of every denomination have apparently abandoned hope of oonTerting the Malays." Palgrave spoke for Turkey and Syria: "All the temporal advantages offered by European protection, not to mention direct persuasion and indirect sub tidies, can scarcely—or, indeed more truly, not at all—procure a single convert to any firm of Christianity, Greek, Armenian, Protestant, or Catholic ; whilst on the other hand, the reverse process enrols yearly a very sensible number from one or other or all other sects." But though Mohamedans so resolutely decline to change their faith, there are countless multitudes of unsophisticated heathens in Africa and the Far Bast who welcome the evangeliser, more or less.

Mohamedanism has a fascination for certain minds in Asia. Père Dan reported in the first quarter of the seventeenth century that the Emperor of Morocco had nearly 8,000 Christian renegades in his service,whilst a single Tarkish renegade could scarcely be found in Christendom. As a rule, no doubt, the motives of European men or women who abjure the Cross will not bear examination ; but Moslems do not' abjare at all. In India the namber of perverts is snoh that when the heads of the faith were solemnly debating whether the land might, still be classed as Dard-Islam, Syed Ahmed Khan, member of the Connoil, pointed out that "We make converts of Christians here, and no one forbids or hinders us"—which settled the question. Even in England there is at least one congregation, claiming four hundred ' communicants" ones Christian. Men and women English born are married at the Mosque by a Mollah, who in private life is a solicitor from the Isle of Man. We are told that London also will have a Mosque before the year is ont, one worthy of the Prophet and the Khalif, who is finding the money.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: The Army Estimates show that provision has been made for the maintenance of 4,008 coming year, at a total cost of £342,779. With reguard to the details, pay absorbs £185,300; medical establishment and medicine, £9,680; conveyance of troops on land 10,150; ditto by sea, Army Service Corps, £7,963; purchase of remounts, 400; provisions, forape, light, fuel, &c. £77,980; clothing, £17,400; wages, Army Ordanance Department, £2,463; engineer services, £2,895; whilst the sum of £14,168 is devoted to buildings and the balance is taken up by education, army accounts, &c. The contribution by the Khedive's Government remians as before, viz, £100,000. The British troops last year numbered 3.243, exclusive of the detachments in Crete.

The force of 4 008 is made up as follows: –– Cavalry (mounted military police) 123; Royal Garrison Artillery, 151; Royal Engineers, 109; Infantry, 3,345 ; Army Service Corps, 88 ; Royal Army Medical Corps, Departmental Corps, 47.
The garrison of Cyprus will consist of 108 infantry, detailed by one of the battalions at Cairo. Its maintenance costs £11,699 per annum.

Captain A. L Hadow, lab Battalion Lincolnshire Regiment, has been selected for service with the Egyptian Army, the namber of British officers attached haring been increased by eight. Captain Hadow has served in the gallant "Holy Boys" since July, 1898, and he got his company in Jane of last year. He was employed ss a transport officer in the Wazitistan Expedition, 1901-02 (medal with clasp), and he was also with the Thibet Mis sion, 1904-5, and was present at the aotion of Naici, and the operations at and round Gyant- 86 and the march to Lhassa. For his services Captain Hadow was mentioned in despatches relative to the doings of the little body of British and native troops which participated in the expedition to the "Roof of the World."

Major B. St. J.Batter, second in command of the 1st Battalion Lincolnshire Regiment, Secunderabad, was promoted to the command of the battalion to-day by the retirement of Colonel M. C. Curry, D.S.O., on the completion of his four years at its head.

The cruiser Lancaster was commissioned today at Chatham by Captain H.L. Heath for another commission in the Third Cruiser Squadron attached to the Mediterranean Fleet. This cruiser carries a complement of 700 officers and men.

The first class cruiser Suffolk will be re-commissioned at Devonporton the 10th April by Captain R.B. Wemyss for another commission with the Third Cruiser Squadron, attached to the Mediterranean Fleet. The Suffolk was commissioned at Devonport on the 31st May, 1904, by Captain David Beatty, D.S.O., for her present commission. She carries a crew of 700 of all ranks.

Captain J. R. Bridson bas been appointed to the command of the cruiser Challenger on the Australian Station from the 22nd inst. Captain Bridson has served for over thirty-one years on blue water, and his held his present rank since June, 1901, and was latterly employed in command of the cruiser Hermione on special service. He was a middy on the battleship Shah daring her historic encounter with the rebel Peruvian turret ship Huasear, off the town of Ylo, 1877.

On the 3rd proxo. a number of ships on the sale list will be sold by public auction at Chatham. Th ese inolnde the Tartar, which was formeriy a freqnent visitor to Alexandrie, while attached to the Mediterranean Fleet.

The scheme for the coming co-operation of the merchant fleets in the naval manœuvre: of Jaoe next is, as already announced in these notes,to be covered by the enormous insurance of £10,000,000. Riakia not the only thing that had to be considered by the Admiralty, for demurrage rates run very high. However, the Admiralty has agreed on a general rate of 3s 9d. percent., which works out at the respectable premium of £18,760 Half of this is to be laid at Lloyd's and the other moiety will be distributed amongst the larger Lon ion companies. The claims will be decided by a small committee consisting of the Chairman of Lloyd's, the Chairman of the Shipping Federation, and the Chairman of the Average Adjusters' Society. During ten days of the mimic war, outward bound ships will group at Falmouth or Milford Haven and then proceed to their destinations under the protection of the squadrons which will be detailed to escort them. Homeward bound ships will group at Gibraltar for a similar purpose. Fast mail ships and passenger ships carrying perishable goods will be exempt from the scheme and also from capture by the "enemy."

div.head: FOREIGN INTERESTS IN TURKEY.
div.p: GERMAN PROGRESS.

In the latest report to the Foregin Office on the trade of Constinople and district for last year, Mr. Consul Waugh, after giving an account of the commercial condition of the country and of the principle articles of trade, and French eyes, by no means the "quantité negligeable" which it seems to have become in those of British investor. As we diminish our holdings in Turkey they are eagerly snapped up by others; and it seems a serious question whether we are not making a mistake in letting go all hold in the country. Only last month the control of the small Mersina-Adana railway, which has figured for years as a British line, was acquired by the Anatolian Railway Co., which bought the majority of shares. The Germans are by year, investing more money in this country. Mention has been made above of German shipping enterprises in these waters. On January 31 appeared a notice of the registration at the German Consulate General here of a Constantinople branch of the Orient Bank of Berlin; capital, 800,000; object banking buisness of all kinds, especially the furthering of trade relations between Germany and the Orient. The German Haidar-Pacha Quay Company, which owns the Constantiople terminus of the Anatolian railway, is about to extend its quays and to build a new silo and elevator 7,500 tons of grain, for a British export house, and two others warehouses, each to hold 20,000 tons of grian. A German cable telegraph service was started last summer from Constantinople to Constatanza, the Romanian port on the Black Sea. There is apparently no difficulty in finding German money for enterprise in Turkey. The only railway in Turkey left to-day in British hands is the Smyrna-Aidin.

div.head: ALDERSHOT RAGGING CASE.
div.p: A young officer of a Guards Regiment, says the "Daily Mail," is at present in London under a doctor's care suffering from complete nervous breakdown.

It appears that this officer, who is not very well off, had declared himself unable to meet the usual subscriptions for regimental purposes. Instead, therefore, of spending his leisure hours with his brother officers he kept much to hit own room. This line of conduct was resented by several officers in the regiment,and they expressed their objection, it is said, by foroibly stripping the yonog fellow, smearing him with motor oil, feathering him, and then plastering his hair with jam.
Eventually, however, the viotim escaped to his room, but he he followed, and when his pursuers were smashing down his door he jumped from his window and sucoeeded in reaching a hotel in the town.

The officers concerned in the ragging tried, but tailed to discover his where boats. Next morning the subaltern went to London and saw a dootor. While at Aldershot he was reported "absent without leave." His doctor, however, sent an explanatory telegram to the colonel reporting that the officer missing was seriously ill. The matter has been reported to Mr. Haldane, who has ordered an inquiry.

div.head: THE KHEDIVES TOUR.
div.p: INTERESTING JOURNEY.
The following details as to the Khedive's recent trip to the Libyan desert have been sent by Reuer's Agency to the London Prise : —

The Khedive left Alexandria for the oasis of Siwa on Feb. 11. He was accompanied by the Vicomte d'Exerpery, Dr. Ritter, Mr. Fats (archecologist), Dr. Kautsky (principal doctor to his Highness) one Egyptian secretary, and one engineer. The Khedive's escort consisted of 8 Egyptian officors, 88 soldiers, 1 coachman, 7 grooms, 8 cooks, 4 servants, 2 tent pitchers,

1 farrier, 5 camelmen, 10 camel-drivers, 4 guides, and 65 Bedouin camel drivers. There were 44 horses, 32 dromedaries, and 25 carrels tor his Highness's personal service, and 246 camels supplied by Bedouins for transport service.

On Feb. 11 the Khedive and suite went by his Highness's private Mariont railway from Alexandria to the terminus of the railway, 135 kilomètres distant. From the terminus they proceeded in motorcars to Side-Abderrahim, 70 kilomètres from the Mariont Railway terminus, and from Side-Abderrahim in a brake, with three horses, driven by the Khedive, to Ras-el-Karrais, 10 kilomètres, where they camped to the night. On the 12th the Khedive drove the brake to Bir-el-Garowla, 40 kilomètres, where they camped for the night.

At Bir-el-Garowla the Khedive was met by a crowd of Bedonins with their sheikhs, who enthusiastically acclaimed the Khedive. The next morning, the 13th, the Khedive droye the brake to Mersa el-Matrouh, twenty kilomètres, accompanied by a crowd of Bedonins and Sikh who make a great fantasia in his honour.

On the 14th the Khedive left Mersa-el- Matrouh for Siwa. The journey, abont 328 kilomètres, was accomplished in seven days. For four days there were wells, but for the last three days there were no wells, water being transported on camel back. On the evening of the 20th the Siwa oasis was reached, and the camp was pitched at the foot of a mountain about five kilometres from Siwa, where many sheikhs and notables welcomed the Khedive. On the morning of the 21st the Khedive and suite entered the town of Siwa, and held a reception in the square in front of the Mamourieh (Government offices). The Khedive remained -five days in the camp near Siwa, and made a careful inspection of the oasis from an agricultural point of view, in order to consider what improvements can be made for the be ferment of cultivation. The Khedive received the merchants and farmers of Siwa, and consulted with them on the commercial and agricultural welfare of the oasis. The Khedive also visited the scanty remains of the temple of Jupiter Ammon.

On the 26th the Khedive and suite, with his escort, left Siwa for Mersa-el-Matrouh, which was reached in six days. On March 4 his Highness left Merra el-Matrouh for Alexandria, where all arrived safe and sound on March 6.

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN OBELISK IN NEW YORK.
div.p: The New York newspapers to hand comment on the fact that they have forgotten to commemorate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the arrival of the Central Park obelisk from Alexandria, where it had lain since the time of the Ptolemies who had removed it from Heliopolis. An American contemporary remarks : "What a shame that we New Yoikers allowed the twenty-fifth anniversary of the arrival of our Heliopolis obelisk to pass without a kindly word of giatitode to old Thothmes III., to William H. Vanderbilt or to Commander Gorringe, U S.N. The first man mentioned set op the granite shaft ; the second obtained it from the Khedive, Ismail Pacha ; the third brought it hither and placed it on the greensward in Central Park. The obelisk was put on board the Dessong, a Hartlepool built tramp at Alexandria. On arriving in America the monolith was taken from the steamship at Staten Island, put aboard a barge and towed to the upper part of the city and rolled laboriously across town to its site. It was set on its base on January 22, 1881, and one month later the city received it. William H. Vanderbilt, who paid all the expenses of its transportation,more than $100 000, was unable to attend the ceremonies because of illness.

div.head: DRUNKENNESS IN BABYLON.
div.p: A postcard at present exhibited in the shop windows says : "If whisky interferes with your business, give up your business." According to Dr. Pinchvs. who lectured at University College lately on the Assyria-Babylon antiquities in the British Museum, the ancients were less depraved than the moderns to whom this advice is tiered. They were winbibber , and wanted to be but even in those day- to get drunk was inconvenient, ard so certain specifics were recommended with a view to enable men to drink liberally without becoming incapable. According to Dr. Pinch the following is a translation of an inscription on one of the monuments in the British Museum : ' The eggs of an owl, given fur three days in wine, bring on a drunkard's weariness. The dried lung of sheep, tak beforehand, drives away drunkenness. The ashes of a swallow's beak, ground up with myrrh, and sprinkled in the wine which drunk, will make secure from drunkeness. Horus, King of the Assyrians, found this out."

div.head: KHEDIVIAL THEATRE.
div.p: M. LE BARGY.

M. Le Bargy and his colleagues gave their seventh and last peiformance on Tuesday night. Le Reveil of Hervieu was the piece, and the acting was as good as any yet seen. The play made soo e sensation in Paris. Prince Grégoire and his son Jean are in France, awaiting the turn of the tide in their native Sylvania which may put Jean on the throne. Jean falls in love with Thérèse de Mégée, the danghter-in law of histjatfrer's old friend, Mme de Mégée. The motif-then is the strugg'e between love, that is Thérèse, and patriotism and honour, as held out by, Prince Grégoire. The son chooses love. The father is forions and contrives to have their rendezvous surprised, Jean enticed out, and Thérèse told that her lover has been killed ; she, mad with grief, is driven out of the house, picked fainting in the Bois, and brought home : finds her daughter in a like state at the prospect of her engagement to a young M. Farmont being broken off, and she has to colleot her forces and help to arrange matters. Incidentally she finds how greatly her own husband loves her : all this so strengthens her that she is able to refuse Jean, brought to life again. He resigns himself to his regal prospects, and is reconciled to his father.

Such is the play, full of passion, ambition, and sacrifices, rather a great pley. M. Le Bargy and Mlle Baréty excelled almost all we have yet seen of them. The others were good, but though M. Poumard did his bast as the old prince, we could not but think of Monnet Sully, who did the part so superbly in Paris. All the traces, however, of overacting and that shade of contempt for the audience which had been noticeable before, disappeared this last performance. It is a pity M. Le Bargy leaves us, as two or three of the plays promised have not been given. But we have had the pleasure of seeing acting of the best Frenoh sohool, in some of the most interesting modern drama. At least that is some consolation after the arid and disappointing programme of the theatrical season. Between the 2nd and 3rd acts a collection was made for the unfortunate Coorrières miners, and LE 120 was realized by the efforts et Mesdames Dauesmond and Bernou, who charmed everyone, even in the bar, into paying at least once. M. Le Bargy thanked the audience in a most eloquent and flattering speech. So ends the Cairo theatrical season for 1905-1906.

div.head: THE LOWER EGYPT CHAPLAINCY FUND.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette " Sir, Will you kindly insert the enclosed appeal for funds to assist the Itinerating Chaplaincy of Lower Egypt? The object is a worthy one and the chaplainoy is an influence for good, especially amongst those whose opportunities of attending Divine Service are few and far between. I hope therefore the appeal will be snccessful. and that sufficient annual subscriptions and donations may be received to enable the chaplaincy to be placed on a permanent basis.
Subscriptions and donations, however small, will be gratefully received and acknowledged.
— I am, etc., Fred. T. Murdoch.
Mansonrsh, March 28.
The following is the text of the circular referred to :—

Sir,—Believing you to be interested in the above, we beg to draw yonr attention to the following facts ; The Chaplaincy was instituted by the Society, for the Propagation of the Gospel in 1902, and a grant of £200 per annum was sanctioned in the hope that the neoessary fonds woold be raised by subscription locally, and the chaplainoy eventoally become self- supporting. In 1904 the society's grant was reduced to £100. In the meantime it had been found necessary to raise the chaplain's stipend to £250. The Rev. Canon F. Utterton of Leatherhead, Surrey, kindly undertook to maka himself responsible for the balance or part of it as could not be met locally. Only £80 was forthcoming from the Delta and the Rov. Canon Utterton had to find some £70. The rent and other expenses of the church rooms at Tantah and Mansoniah (£18 and £25 respectively) and the chaplain's travelling expemes between the two places were paid out of offertories and local subscriptions and donations. Tho furniture of the church rooms (more especially that at Mansonrsh) was generously provided by Mr. G. B. Alderson, Bishop Byth, and others.

The chaplain resides at Mansonrah in the same building as that in which the church room is situated, renting the rest of the flat. Alternate morning and evening services are held every Sunday at Mansonrsh and Tantah, and occasional visits have been paid to Ksfrel Zayat, Damanborir, and Constantinia. Even Assiout and Beni-Souef have been reached.

The Rev. Canon Utterton has been compelled to, withdraw his guarantee and, under these circumstances, there is grave danger of the chaplaincy having to be abandoned for lack of, sufficient funds to meet the expenses. It is felt, however, that with a litte help from Alexandria and Cairo and other towns in Egypt, this useful work might be carried on and the chaplaincy eventually become permanent. We need barely point out that there is an ever increasing number of Britishsubjects is resident in Egyptain villages remote from any church or religous service of their own faith, and for their sake it is important that this chaplaincy should not be allowed to fall through.
Annual subscriptions or donations may be sent to : Fred. T. Murdich, British consular agent
Mansonrsh, W.C.E. Smith, Mansourah F Murrel Wright, Tantah, and A. J. Wskeman Long, Tantah.

div.head: VICTORIA COLLEGE ATHLETIC SPORTS.
div.p: The annual athletic sports of Victoria College took place on Wednesday last in the presence of some 2,000 spectators, including a large number of parents and friends of the boys, who took the liveliest interest in the proceedings. This, notwithstanding the fact that the afternoon was as unpleasant as it could well be. A strong khamseen wind was blowing, and the clouds of dust which repeatedly swept across the grounds rendered it anything but enjoyable to be out. The weather, however, did not affect the sports, the programme of which was carried through with the greatest success, thanks to the perfect organisation of the committee, which was composed of Messrs. A Morrison and E. A. Aubrey (judges), A. Mustard (starter), F. G. Lowick (clerk of the course), and A. G. Lias (timekeeper). The boys evinoed the greatest interest in the varions events, and it was a pleasure to watch them acquitting themselves so creditably. At the conclusion of the sports, Mrs. E. B. Gould graciously distributed the prizes (which had been presented by some frierds of the sohool) to the successful competitors. Mrs. A. S. Preston made a beautiful bouquet, which was presented to Mrs. Gould by the smallest prize winner, H. El Magri.

Mr. and Miss Lias were "at home" on the occasion of the sports and received their guests with the utmost hospitality. A well-stocked buffet had been erected under a marquee and here tea and light refreshments were lavishly dispensed. Among Mr. and Miss Lias' guests we noticed the Earl and Countess of Meath, who spent the afternoon at the sohool before leaving for Cairo.
The gronnds were beantifully decorated with flag kindly lent by Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield Mr. A. S. Preston supplied the chairs. The following is a list of the prizewinners :—
1. Long Jump .(under 5 ft. 4 in.)—14, G. N.
Dahan ; 2nd, J. D. Frazer.
2. High Jump (under 5 ft. 4 in.)—14, J D. Frazer; 2nd, G Arab and M G. Dara- malli.
3.Long Jump (open).—1st, M. S. Yaghen ; 2nd, C. Pappa. The winner jumped very prettily, clearing 16 ft. 5 in.
4. 220 yards (nnder 5 ft. 4 in).—1st, G. Frangi; 2nd, N. G. Dahan.
5.Quarter mile (open).—1st, R. Frangi ; 2nd, M. S Yaghen. Frangi ran very wall and won by fifteen yards.
6. 150 yards (under 4 ft. 5 in )—1st, Q. Mires; 2nd, H. Landaner.
7. High Jnmp (open). — 1st,' M S. Yaghen ; 2nd, T. Cheori. The winner cleared 4 it. 6m.
8. Quarter-mile (order 4 fr. 8 in.)—1st, D. Ralli ; 2nd, S Hsggar. A fine raoe, and a dose finish between two of the fastest of the smaller competitors
9.120 yards (nnder 3 ft. 8 in.) — 1st, H. el-
Masri ; 2nd M. Salama.
10. Half-mile Handicap — 1st, M. J. Khalifa ; 2nd, F. Stent ; 3rd, J. Matta. For this race there were 114 entries.
11. 120 yards Hurdles (open).—1st, T. Cheori 2nd, M. S. Yaghen. Cheori took the hurdles well and won easily.
12. 100 yards (under 4 ft. 8 in.) — let, 8. Haggar ; 2nd, D. Ralli.
13. 100 yards (open). - 1st, R. Frangi ; 2nd, M. 8. Ysghen.
14. Half-mile (nnder 5 ft. 4 in ) — 1st, G. Frangi ; 2nd, M. Cnriel.

15. One mile (open).— 1st, G. Valassoponlo ; 2nd, G. Frangi ; 3rd, S. Lagonioo. Valas; sopoulo ran steadily from the start, with a good stride. Frangi held on very pluckily for three laps and then fell away. Lagonico was a good third.
M. Abon el Ezz and A. Nimr deserve special mention. Both ran and jumped well.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA AMATEUR ATHLETIC SPORTS.
div.p: The entries for the forthcoming athletic sports are abobve those of last year, excepting in the open events, where there is a great falling-off. This is a pity, with such handsome prizes to be competed for. Athletically the meeting should be a very fine one and the classic event, the 109 yards, is a very open thing. For the jumps the entries are good, and the polo jump names include the winner of the Cairo Olympic Games at this branch of sport. He should win it as his most dangerous opponent is untrained owing to injuries and is also penalized. The children's race has entry of about forty, and the spectacle of this sprint should ha most picturesque. The prizes will be on view in the windows of Mersrs Davies Bryan and Co. to night. On Wednesday all trams will stop at the Spoiting Club station between the hours of l p.m. and 7 p.m.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA CENTRAL BUILDINGS CO.
div.p: The tint annual general meeting of this company was held yesterday afternoon in the offices of Messrs. Hewat and Company. Mr Kranois Allen, the Chairman of the Company, made the following speech : —

Gentlemen,—I do not know that I need add mcuh to the information placed before you in the report just read, but I think yon will agree with me that it is a satisfactory and significant fact that the company is able to pay such a dividend as 4% for the first year of its existence, and when only a portion of its property is developed. If all continues to go well your beard hopes that for the carrent year a somewhat increased dividend-may be possible. Of the vaine of your property there can be only one opinion; if I might be allowed the comparison, its position in the centre of the City of Alexandria is similar to that of the Bank of England to London, and its possibilities are immense. It will be the objeot of yonr Directors to develop these possibilities to the utmost. Although speaking generally the public in Egypt is more disposed to speculative investments, there is, nevertheless, a considerable body of prndent investors to whom the security offered by the company's 4% First Mortgage Debentures appeals. A small amount was placed prior to Slat Decern, but since then considerable progress has been made, and your directors anticipate no difficulty in placing the remainder ''an for et à mesure," as they are required for construction. The construction of the east blook is well in hand, and your directors hope that it will be completed in eighteen months time. This blook will consist of ground and four floors and will be supplied with electric lifts and all modern conveniences.
Directors' Report.
The report of the directors, Messrs. Allen, Escoffier, Eingham and Wellhoff, is as follows:—

Suivant les dispositions de l'Art. 31 des Statuts, nons vous avons oonvoqués en Assem blée Générale Ordinaire, pour vous soumettre notre premier rapport sur la situation des affaires sooiales, ainsi que le Bilan et le Compte Profits et Pertes de la Société pour l'exeroioe arrêté le 81 Décembre 1905. Pendant l'exeroioe qui nous oooupe nous avons terminé la oonstrnction de l'Immeuble "West Blook" et oommenoé la oonstruotion de l'Immeuble "East Blook." Ponr faire face aux frais de oonstruotion de ce dernier, et aux termes de l'Art 45 des Statuts, nons avons décidé une première émission d'Obligations poor la somme de £40,000, que nous avons déjà en partie placée an tanx d'intérêt de 4%. Le Bilan étant suffisamment détaillé, nons ne oroyons pas nécessaire de vous donner des explications là- dessus. D'après le Compte Profits et Pertes les bénéfices de l'année se sont élevés à la somme de P.T. 412,031. Et ajoutant aux bénéfices de l'exercice le reliquat reporté de l'année dernière le montant vous revenant serait de P.T. 417,034,8.

Sur oette somme nons vous proposons de payer nn dividende de 4 % œ qui absorbera la somme de P.T. 390.000, et de reporter à nouveau, après déduotion faite -de la somme de P.T. 12,360, revenant à voûte Conseil d'Administration d'après l'Art 97 des Statuts, le solde de P.T. 14,674,8. Vous avez à procéder à l'éjection de deux membres de votre Conseil df Administration. Lés membres sortant cette année Bont MM Allen'et Eingham. Nous vous rappelons qu'ils sont rééligibles. Vous aurez en outre à nommer on Censenr pour l'exeroice 1906 et à fixer' sa rémunération.
Auditors' Report.
The auditor, Mr. P. Petcovich reports as follows :—

Conformément au mandat qne votre Conseil d'Administration m'a conféré, j'ai prooédé à la vérification des Comptes de votre Compagnie pour l'Exercice 1905 et j'ai constaté la parfaite régularité des livres et de la Comptabilité en général et leur conoordanoe avec les pièoes à l'appui que j'ai examinées. Le bilan qoi vous est soumis par votre ConBeil d'Administration représente exactement la situation de la Corn pagnie au 31 Décembre 1Î05. Le Compte de Profits et Pertes donne nn solde de P.T. 417.084,8, qni représente, sauf une somme de P.T. 5,013.8, reporté de l'Bxfroioe précédent, le montant des bénéfices nets de l'Exercice 1905. Je n'ai donc qu'à vous proposer, Messieurs, de donner votre approbation aux comp tes qui voub sont soumis par votre Conseil d'Administration.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, 29 Mars.
Le tanx de l'esoompte à Londres vient d'être encore réduit de 1/8 à 3 3/8 pour cent.
Au Stock Exchange, hier, le Consolidé anglais a bausré de 1/4 à 90 5/8. L'Unifiée, la National Bank, l'Agricolo et la Daïra se sontmainto nues à leurs prix précédente.
A Parie, l'aotion Crédit Foncier Egyptien a baissé de 6 francs à 792. La Banque d'Athènes est renseignée en reprise de 1 frano à 152.
Sans avoir donné lien A beaucoup de mouvement ni à de grandes variations, notre marohé des valeurs a montré, ce matin, plusde fermeté et d'animation qne les jonrs précédents.
La National Bank, très sontenne, a clôturé à 27 15/16—28 l'aotion anoienne, et 27 1/8 la nouvelle. En bonne tendanoe également, l'A- grioole s'est inscrite à 9 15/16—10.
L'action Crédit Foncier s'est maintenue à 794-95. La Daïra est demeurée immobile à 18 1/4. La Nile Land a avancé à 8.

Les actions Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux ont été. traitées à 4 1/16—j^â/32 ; la p«/rt de fondateur est restée à L.E. 15 1/2. La faiblesse relative qni se manifeste sàrlenours des notions pourrait, à première voe, causer de l'étonnement, car les affaires de la Société vont très bien. Elle est cependant explioable, en raison dn deuxième àppe', exigible le 2 avril proohain ; il y a, en effet, des personnes qui, ponr s'épargner le versement, préfèrent vendre aveo un bénéfice de 1/8 on de 1/4, an lieu de garder un titre appelé à donner an profit sérieux an premier bilan. L'aohat, an cours aotuel, nons semble tont-indiqué.

Un bon mouvement s'est produit sur les titres de la Brasserie des Pyramides sur la nouvelle que la vente des terrains de la Sooiété aurait été définitivement conolne hier soir. L'aotion a haussé à 152 ponr clôturer à 150 sur des réalisations ; le dividende a fini à 90 après avoir atteint 92 1/9.
L'action ordinaire Khédivial Mail a avancé à 41 sh. 9. La part de fondateur Menzaleh est remontée à 130-135.
Dane le groupe des Hôtels, les Nnngovioh ont été poussés de 17 5/8 à 18 1/8.

Le compartiment des (retitea valeurs a été calme. Bénis, les New Egyptian ont été aotive ment éohaogés poor clôturer à 36 sb. 8. Les Glymenopoulo ont fait 1 1/2—9/16 et Cotton Mills ont été ramenés à 6 sh. 9.

Par suite dn développement considérable et prospère qu'ont pris ses affaires, la New Egyptian Co. a décidé d'émettre 146.940 aotiona nouvelles, au prix avantageux de 30 sh. l'ao tion. Les actionnaires aotnels auront droit à une aotion nouvelle ponr deux anoienne?. Les aotions nouvelles jouiront absolument des mô mes droits qne les anoiennes pour ce qui est do dividende prochain.

div.head: SEMOULERIE PERFECTIONNEE
div.p: "LELYS"

J'ai l'honneur d'informer le public et plus spécialement ma respeotable olientèle que, tout en gardant mon moulin 4 farines de Tarsoos (Turquie d'Asie), fondé en 1890, je viens d'installer 4 Alexandrie une seraoulerie de tout dernier modèle fonctionnant d'après les systèmes perfectionnés les plus réoents de Franoe et de Suisse. Grèce à ma longue expérienoe dans ce genre d'industrie, ainsi qu'aux moyens exceptionnels dont je dispose pour m'approvisionner en blés de tout premier choix en Syrie, dans le Levant et en Russie, j'espère pouvoir donner pleine et entière satisfaction sous tous les rapports.
Dans l'espoir que vous voudrez bien me conserver votre pratique et faire l'essai du produit de ma nouvelle usine,
Agréez etc.
Gabriel Marino.
Mon bureau se trouve à côté de la Poste de Ras-el-Tin.—Téléphone N° 17-68—et la fabrique dans le même quartier, Rue Gouda.
P.S.— On peut se proourer dans le même établissement du son, des criblures et de la farine

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound

div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.
